channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: DealBook: For Russia, Ruble Crisis Is Testing Its Resources
item.description: The country’s finance ministry said it was prepared to sell as much as $7 billion of its foreign currency reserves to support the ruble, which an official called “extremely undervalued.”
item.dc:creator: By JENNY ANDERSON
item.media:description: Prime Minister Dmitry A. Medvedev of Russia, center, held a meeting on economic issues on Wednesday in Moscow.

item.title: Journey to Rapprochement Visited Worlds of Presidents, Popes and Spies
item.description: The deal that restored full diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba ultimately rested with a spy swap.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Obama speaking with Cuba’s president, Raúl Castro, on Tuesday. On Wednesday, Mr. Obama ordered the restoration of full diplomatic relations.

item.title: Snow Is Down and Heat Is Up in the Arctic, Report Says
item.description: The Arctic continued to warm faster than the rest of the globe, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Arctic Report Card.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: As sea ice retreats, more sunlight reaches the upper layers of the sea, leading to more phytoplankton blooms, seen here in the Bering Sea this fall.

item.title: Colombian Rebels Call Unilateral Truce
item.description: Colombia’s largest guerrilla group declared on Wednesday that it was about to begin an indefinite, unilateral cease-fire, in a challenge to the government to halt hostilities while the two sides continued negotiations toward an end to 50 years of war.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: As Havana Celebrates Historic Shift, Economic and Political Hopes Rise
item.description: The sweeping changes President Obama outlined will have a profound impact on Cuba — where isolation by the United States has fundamentally shaped the island’s economy, its politics and even its national identity.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD, VICTORIA BURNET, T and DAMIEN CAVE.
item.media:description: In Havana, watching President Raul Castro speak on Wednesday about normalizing relations with the United States.

item.title: In Miami, Astonishment Over Action and Disagreement Over Cuba News
item.description: In a city with more Cubans than anywhere but Cuba, what some see as wrongheaded, others see as overdue.
item.dc:creator: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ and NICK MADIGAN

item.title: U.S. Frees Last of the ‘Cuban Five,’ Part of a 1990s Spy Ring
item.description: Three members of the Cuban Five — part of a spy ring that infiltrated exile groups in Florida in the 1990s — were released from prison as part of the sudden diplomatic thaw in relations.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: A billboard in Havana with Fidel Castro and the Cuban Five, left, spies who infiltrated exile groups in South Florida and who were also freed on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. to Restore Full Relations With Cuba, Erasing a Last Trace of Cold War Hostility
item.description: The U.S. will open an embassy in Havana for the first time in more than a half century after the release of an American contractor held in prison for five years, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Alan Gross arrives at a news conference on Wednesday with his wife, Judy, in Washington.

item.title: Horror Paralyzes Pakistan After a Methodical Slaughter
item.description: With flags at half-staff and businesses shuttered, Pakistanis seemed to be trapped between grief, anger and frustration, for once overcoming their divisions to unite in pain.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN
item.media:description: A soldier on guard Wednesday at the Army Public School in Peshawar. The school was attacked Tuesday by Taliban gunmen, who killed 148 people.

item.title: Alan P. Gross Gains the Freedom From Cuba He Thought Would Never Come
item.description: The release of Mr. Gross, who was detained on Dec. 3, 2009, and labeled a spy, was part of a historic thaw in Cuban-American relations announced by President Obama.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Alan P. Gross, center, prepared to speak at his lawyer's office in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Letter From China: Reporters in China Say Media Freeze Is Intensifying
item.description: Progress on visa renewals for journalists obscures what many correspondents say is a mounting hostility toward Western media outlets operating in China.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Patrolling a Disputed Line, Israeli Border Police Become a Focus of Anger
item.description: The border police, whose green berets are a nod to the Green Line that demarcated Israeli territory from its hostile neighbors in 1949 armistice agreements, serve in the most sensitive situations.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Israel’s border police in East Jerusalem. The force is leading a crackdown in the city after a spate of terror attacks.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: The Taliban's Massacre in Peshawar Must Be Its Last
item.description: For too long, Pakistanis were in denial about the terror in their midst.
item.dc:creator: By MIRA SETHI and SHEHRBANO TASEER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Hectoring Venezuela on Human Rights
item.description: Instead of punishing my country, the U.S. should check its own record.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIOSDADO CABELLO

item.title: Russia Introduces Measures to Calm Economic Jitters
item.description: By Wednesday evening, amid indications of a government intervention in the currency markets, the ruble had recovered more than 11 percent of its previous day’s losses.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: U.S. Said to Find North Korea Ordered Cyberattack on Sony
item.description: American intelligence officials have concluded that the government of Kim Jong-un was centrally involved in the attacks on the film company’s computers.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: Sony dropped plans to release “The Interview.”

item.title: World Briefing: German Soldiers May Help Train Forces in Iraq
item.description: Germany’s cabinet approved a plan for 100 soldiers to help train Kurdish pesh merga forces.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: World Briefing: Foul Play Ruled Out in German Politician’s Death
item.description: Andreas Schockenhoff, a well-known critic of Russia, died last weekend of heart failure or heat exposure, an autopsy showed.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Taking Cuba Off the Blacklist Leaves Only North Korea as Cold War Vestige
item.description: Political historians said the steps announced on Wednesday were akin to the steps taken to normalize relations with China and Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Images of late North Korean leaders Kim Jong Il and Kim Il Sung were illuminated on a building in the capital, Pyongyang, in June.

item.title: Pakistan Urges Afghans to Help Find Taliban Leaders Behind Massacre
item.description: Gen. Raheel Sharif went to Afghanistan to seek help in locating the Pakistani Taliban commanders who orchestrated the Peshawar school massacre.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: A soldier stood guard amid the damage at the Army Public School in Peshawar on Wednesday, a day after the massacre by the Pakistani Taliban.
